hackathon-description-text: We want to seed ideas, connections, and projects that will make the breast pump experience not suck so much. Covening talented people for a weekend is a first step. We also see this as an opportunity to catalyze innovation in maternal and pediatric health more generally.

hackathon-judges.judge-role: Vecna Technologies, Inc., Innovation in Global Health for the Developing World

hackathon-eligibility: You must be signed up for the event. Tickets available:
hackathon-requirements: Please include a full description of your solution and include screen shots.

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: First Prize & Trip to Silicon Valley

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=75 Amherst Street, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: How innovative is the project? Innovation might mean building on an existing platform or creating something new.
What's the potential of this project to impact a large number of people? Here we will look at cost and accessibility concerns. Is this only an innovation for the 1%?
How well did the project take into account the concerns of real people? Did they listen to users, peruse the data set of user stories and design something to meet a real-world need?
How well did the team document their idea? Did they communicate it clearly in the presentation? Does the documentation inspire us?
Does the team include a range of backgrounds and skills? Did the team seek to round out expertise they might be missing (e.g. hardware design or lactation consulting or pumping mom feedback)?
Did the team embrace collaboration in the spirit of open innovation and problem-solving?

hackathon-location-address: 75 Amherst Street, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA
hackathon-description-header: On Sept 20-21, 2014, 150 parents, engineers, designers and healthcare givers will gather at the MIT Media Lab for the Make the Breast Pump Not Suck Hackathon.
